full_summary:
# Government of Canada Tender Announcement
## Title: Renovations to Government of Canada Building in Lower Sackville, NS
### Reference Number: cb-8942-52791977
### Amendment Number: 4
### Solicitation Number: M4000-4-2386

## Tender Overview

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) intends to retain a Contractor to provide construction services for interior renovations to a Government of Canada building in Lower Sackville, NS. The expected duration of the project is 40 weeks from the contract award date.

## Tender Information
### Tender Status: Expired
### Unspsc: Renovation of buildings or landmarks or monuments, Commercial and office building construction services
### Procurement Category: Construction Services (CNST)
### Procurement Method: Competitive - Open bidding
### Selection Criteria: Lowest Price
### Regions of Opportunity: Worldwide
### Regions of Delivery: Nova Scotia

## Tender Documents

The tender documents, including the Invitation to Tender (ITT) and security requirements, can be downloaded from the Canada Buys website: https://canadabuys.canada.ca/en/tender-opportunities

## Bidder Requirements

To be eligible to respond to this tender, Bidders must meet the mandatory security requirements outlined in the ITT.

## Tender Process

The tender process consists of two phases:

1.  Phase One Qualifications: Bidders will be evaluated on a pass or fail basis for their ability to meet the mandatory requirements.
2.  Phase Two Price: The responsive Bidders from Phase One will be invited to submit a price bid. The Bidder with the lowest price will be recommended for contract award.

## Contact Information

For further information, please contact:
Beth Churchill
Email: beth.churchill@rcmp-grc.gc.ca
Phone: (902) 720-5450
Address: 80 Garland Ave, H066, Dartmouth, NS B3B 0J8, Canada

## Important Notes

Canada retains the right to negotiate with any supplier on any procurement. Indigenous Procurement: The federal Indigenous Business Directory (IBD) is an online resource for all levels of government and the private sector to identify Indigenous business capacity. Having a business profile in the IBD will increase your company’s visibility and may provide additional business. A profile in the IBD can also allow you to compete for federal government contracts that are set-aside for Indigenous businesses through the Procurement Strategy for Indigenous Businesses.
